name: Araona

rows: sin filo, mocho, desafilado, embotado, romo
mitu, montete (Peru), paujil/panjuil (Peru), paujil de Salvin (Peru for Mitu salvini)
Northern Amazonia (N of Solimões), not in northern Colombia; Dark-winged trumpeter is found south of Solimões
Different types have different localized ranges
Respectively: 'lechuza cornuda'; small red owl. A white owl is zao. *Tacn form is *popo.
loro real, loro (Sp. form is a loan from Carib)
sachaperro, Perro de Monte, Zorro Vinagre, Guanfando; Zorro Ojizarco, Zorro Negro, Perro de Orejas Corta
oso hormiguero; tapia pelejo or pelejo chico for Cyclopes didactylus
Myrmecophaga tridactyla (giant anteater); Cyclopes didactylus (silky anteater)
armadillo, carachupa (Peru), yangunturi (Peru for Giant armadillo)
family Dasypodidae; e.g. Priodontes maximus (Giant armadillo), Dasypus novemcinctus, Dasypus kappleri
Melanosuchus niger, Caiman schlerops; Paleosuchus sp.
Port term reportedly borrowed from Tupi
maparate (used in Peru for some types of catfish, including Auchenipterus sp.), cunchi (used in Peru for some types of catfish), bagre (catfish)
iguana' is reportedly from Arawak iwana
boa; mantona (red-tailed boa); boa de altura
Yellow-footed: Geochelone denticulata; Red-footed: Geochelone carbonaria
Water turtle is ena-dati. *Tacn form is *dati.
Downstream of major rapids and waterfalls
prioritize generic term that includes any edible species
Mature forests of Rio Negro and Upper Amazon
may be confused in some entries with O. bataua
moriche (Col, Ven), aguaje (Col, Peru), achual, miriti
Brazil, Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador, French Guiana, Guyana, Peru, Venezuela; in and near swamps
pui, irapay, hoja de irapay, caraná
Mauritiella armata OR Lepidocaryum tenue (irapay), Mauritius carana
Mauritia carana is limited principally to the Rio Negro and Upper Orinoco regions; dry catinga forests
chontaduro (Col, Ecuador); pipire (Col); pijuayo (Peru), pijiguao (Ven); tembe (Bol)
ungurahui (Peru), palma de seje, milpesos, patabá
mostly north of Equator; common in Amazonia
may be confused with O. bacaba - compare entries
secondary scrub vegetation. lower alt. of eastern Andes
Gossypium (barbadense: long fibers; hirsutum: short fibers)
ceiba, huimba, lupuna (Peru for Ceiba sp.)
northern South America and central America; common in disturbed areas
Capsicum sp., principally chinensis and frutescens
maní (may be loan from Taino Arawak), cacahuete
caña flecha, caña brava, caña isana
banano, banana, cambur, bellaco, variedad de plátano
secondary scrub vegetation and indigenous gardens
Secondary scrub vegetation and indigenous gardens. North and South America (Brazil, Peru, Bolivia, Suriname, Colombia)
secondary scrub vegetation and indigenous gardens
tortuga caspi, pretina (Peru for tree and tumpline); carahuasca (Peru)
Duguetia sp. OR Fusaea longifolia OR Guatteria chrysopetala
castanha do para (B. excelsa); castanha de cutia (C. edulis)
Bertholletia excelsa [cf. Couepia edulis 'castanha do cutia']

1) Couepia: restricted area within Brazil, Rio Purus basin and middle Solimões.  2) Bertholletia: elev: consistently about 200m; mature forests. Widely distributed from Peru, E. Colombia, Brazil to Nicaragua.
anarcado, castaña de cajú, nuez de la India, marañon, cajú, merey (Venezuela)
secondary scrub vegetation and indigenous gardens
tree; most sources will not distinguish between occidentale and other varieties
jagua, majagua - Colombia, caruto, xagua - Venezuela, bigrande - Bolivia, huito, yaguayagua - Peru, ygualti - Nicaragua, maluco - Mexico
native to NW Amazonia, found primarily in Vaupes and Caqueta regions
other species of Pouteria exist and have much-used edible fruit; these can be subsituted where relevant
uva de monte, uvilla (Peru), puruma, caime, caimarona (and variants; Col.)
grows wild in Western Amazon basin; cultivated in Colombia since pre-Colombian times
a tree; not a true grape

not generally cultivated in western (subAndean) Amazon. Arroyo-Kalin (2010) argues for a correlation with distribution of dark earths, mostly formed after 1AD, and the modeled-incised pottery tradition.
Primary staple in western/subAndean Amazonia, less important elsewhere
No processing required, but lower starch yield and pest resistance than bitter variety
Other varieties are lopoa halili, yellow s.p.; haona halili, purplish s.p.; halili selena, red s.p.; tala; zala, 'gualusa'. *Tacn form is *xariri.

calabazo, calabaza; auyama (Dominican Republic and Venezuela), ayote (parts of Central America), zapallo (parts of South America), tutumo/totumo/totuma (Cresc tree), huingo (Peru for Crescentia cujete), tapara
Crescentia cujete (round variety - tree); (Cucurbita) Lagenaria siceraria (bottle variety - vine)
secondary forests and secondary srcrub  vegetation
Respectively: 'barbasco'(root); and a leaf poison. To poison (fish) is kʷia. *Tacn form is *ac̷a.
semi-domesticated, native to Amazonian basin, esp. NW
Also tapi-tapi, 'cazadora grande'; zoi-zoi, 'cazadora pequeña'; makʷa, 'leaf-cutter'. Also bona; malo, 'tucandera'. Also masisi.
bullet ant, lesser giant hunter ant
conga, hormiga yanabe (Colombia), isula (Peru), Hormiga Veinticuatro
Colombia: zampopo, hormiga arriera; Venezuela: bachaco; Peru: curuhuinse
Apis mellifera; Tetragonisca angustula; Trigona amazonensis
lampírido, luciérnaga (Peru), añañahui (Peru), cocuyo   (attributed Taino origin)
The former is poisonous. Also ešo; and c̷oho, fruit worm. *Tacn form is *ec̷ena.
A 'tábano' is weno-weno; also danabo, a black fly; and tepesi.
Also biwa kaleši, a black spider.
Mono Lanudo Común, Choro, Churucu, mono choro (Peru), mono lanudo cafe, barrigudo de Humboldt
mono negro (Peru), Machín Negro, Maicero Cachón, mono maicero
Machín Blanco, mono blanco, Maicero Cariblanco, mono blanco (Peru)
Machin Blanco, Mono Araña de Vientre Amarillo, maquisapa (Peru), braceadora (Colombia)
Lobo Grande de Río, nutria gigante, lutria
Nutria, Lobo de Agua, lobito de rio, perro de agua (Colombia)
sajino, pecarí de collar, jabalf, Javelina, Saíno, Pecarí de Collar
Guatusa Negra, Añuje, Agutí (black-rumped), picure, jochi colorado
Guatín, Punchana, curi, picurito rabudo, picurito rabilargo
Cuniculus paca (Agouti paca is sometimes used as well although cuniculus is the correct term.)
Also hike-baba 'rata terrestre'; ewaepo hike; a tree rat is bakʷehe hike. *Tacn form is *śite.
abalorio, mostacilla, cuenta, gota, puca; necklace=collar
Small black seed, perforated is ewasohohaha; small seeds, bizikewa; red and black seed, pone-pone-haha; section of scorpion tail, used for beads, ahi tika.
Refers to a seat. See 'sit' 12.130. *Tacn form is *waŕi.
Used to be used by Tukanoan peoples (and others?), sound carried for long distances

In RN region, there is typically one person per village (if that) who is a full-fledged 'shaman'. He is very much a specialist and has considerable power to cure, as well as power to curse. He is respected and feared. Shamans are thought to turn themselv

Refers to a lower-level healer; in RN region, most older men in a village have this capacity, and command a repertoire of healing spells. Power is primarily for good, whereas the true shaman is capable of malignant acts as well.
The 'cushma', man's bark-cloth garment is kʷabomala. A sling over the shoulder to carry the baby is ona. *Tacn form is *ona.
malignant forest spirit, covered with long hair, feet turned backward; in Upper Rio Negro region
espíritu malo, espíritu maligno, fantasma, demonio
Some names of gods are: baba-zoto; baba-wotesa; baba-bizosa; baba ewo-o; baba-c̷aha doc̷i; c̷ekʷa-esi; c̷ekʷa mala.
carrizo, zampoñas, flautas de pan, rondadora
The former also means 'string'. The latter is twisted bark. *Tacn form is *bado.
yurupari, jurupari (or any flutes forbidden to women)
a ritual complex in various parts of Amazonia involving sacred flutes/trumpets, forbidden to women.
fetiche, encanto, filtro de amor,  pusanga
Means 'white cane'; 'tacuara' is moi. *Tacn form is *šita.
Salt lick' is mehe. A seasoning, bano, is made from darkly roasted Brazil nuts, pounded in a trough. *Tacn form is *bano.
currently limited to certain groups (favoring h-g orientation, e.g. Nadahup) within RN region
esp. for fanning a cooking fire
Interesting correlation to 'fish' in Tukanoan languages
esp. for grating manioc, but can be used for other things as well
grid of sticks for smoking meat or placing objects (shelf)
pilón, mano de mortero, mazo, moledor
prioritizes manioc beer where distinction is made
usually manioc; agriculture, but also can be made from certain wild seeds/fruits
tipiti, matafrio, sebucán, exprimador, prensa para yuca
word of Tupi origin; agriculture: specifically for squeezing poison out of manioc
hunting, currently is falling out of use in Vaupés region, associated primarily with h-g groups (but this may be recent?)
agriculture? commonly used for sifting dry manioc flour
can refer to worms; more generic
if different word from top grinding stone
use word for top grinding stone if different from bottom stone
The front of the house is e-tae kʷac̷a, lit. 'house-mouth' 04.240. *Tacn form is *e-taŕe.
